name: Strategic Family Therapy (SFT)
summary: Strategic Family Therapy is a structured, problem-focused approach to family counseling that aims to change dysfunctional interaction patterns and resolve presenting problems within families.
description: Strategic Family Therapy (SFT) is a therapeutic model developed in the 1970s at the Mental Research Institute (MRI) in Palo Alto and further refined by Salvador Minuchin and Jay Haley. It focuses on identifying dysfunctional family interaction patterns and creating targeted interventions to disrupt them. SFT is directive, time-limited, and goal-oriented, often using reframing, paradoxical interventions, and tasks assigned to family members between sessions. The therapy addresses family dynamics directly, emphasizing solutions rather than deep exploration of past causes.

off_label_uses: Improving family communication in non-clinical settings
contraindications: Families with ongoing severe domestic violence
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and non-invasive; may temporarily increase conflict as issues are addressed.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Research supports effectiveness in addressing adolescent behavioral issues and substance use, with consistent improvements in family functioning.

sections.text: SFT works by identifying and altering problematic interactional sequences within families. The therapist assumes an active role, introducing strategies such as reframing problems, prescribing tasks, and using paradoxical interventions to shift dynamics. By disrupting rigid interactional cycles, families are guided toward more functional and adaptive communication and problem-solving patterns.

sections.preparation: Therapist establishes rapport with the entire family and defines the presenting problem clearly.
procedure: Identify dysfunctional patterns maintaining the problem.
Introduce reframes to shift perception of problems.
Assign homework tasks to alter behavior patterns.
Use paradoxical or strategic interventions to challenge rigidity.
sections.duration: 8–20 sessions depending on complexity of family issues.

sections.pre_session: Review of previous homework and family progress.
sections.treatment_phase: Live observation and intervention in family interactions.
sections.post_session: Assignment of tasks, reflection, and feedback.

immediate: Increased awareness of family interaction patterns
long_term: Improved adolescent behavior and family cohesion

common: Temporary increases in conflict as patterns are disrupted

relative: Families with highly resistant members unwilling to participate

ideal_candidates: Adolescents with behavioral or substance-related problems
Parents struggling with consistent discipline strategies
screening_required: Willingness of family members to participate

practitioner: Therapists with specialized training in strategic and systemic family therapy approaches

studies: Szapocznik, J., & Kurtines, W. (1989). Breakthroughs in Family Therapy with Drug Abusing and Problem Youth.
sections.limitations: While effective for family and adolescent issues, fewer large-scale RCTs exist compared to other family therapy models.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under family therapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective for adolescent behavioral and substance use interventions compared to residential care

sections.adolescents: Particularly effective for behavioral and substance-related issues.
sections.older_adults: Can be adapted to address intergenerational family conflict.

items: SFT is directive and therapist-driven, often differing from collaborative approaches.
Tasks assigned outside of sessions are essential for success.
Therapists may employ paradoxical strategies, such as prescribing the symptom.
